description: Onomatopoeic, from the sound made when a person runs while wearing daps.

entries.meaning: (West Country, Somerset, Bristol, Wales, usually in the plural) A plimsoll.

verbs.description: dap (third-person singular simple present daps, present participle dapping, simple past and past participle dapped)

entries.meaning: (Bristol) To run or go somewhere quickly.
examples: I'll just dap down to the shop.

entries.meaning: (fishing) To drop the bait gently onto the surface of the water.

description: US 1971, originally by black soldiers during the Vietnam war, associated with Black Power movement. Originally an elaborate handshake, later specifically a fistbump.

Verb originally give dap. Presumably onomatopoeic, or influenced by tap, dab, etc. Alternatively, from earlier slang usage as abbreviation of dapper. Also explained as an acronym, such as “Dignity for Afro People” or “Dignity And Pride”; this may be a backronym or unrelated, but accords with phrasal use as “give DAP” (compare “give respect”). More speculative etymologies derive it from Vietnamese đẹp (“beautiful”), though this is unlikely.

examples: ... where many officers look the other way when blacks ‘give dap’ (the power shake) ...

verbs.description: dap (third-person singular simple present daps, present participle dapping, simple past and past participle dapped)
